docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Arthur Schlesinger Jr. (Op-Ed, Feb. 28) deplores the hypocrisy of those who protest the award of an honorary Oscar to Elia Kazan. Most readers are undoubtedly familiar with the ennobling sentiments Mr. Schlesinger has expressed on behalf of an open, just and democratic society in such classics as ''The Vital Center'' and ''The Disuniting of America.'' But there also seems to be a paradoxical side to his vaunted liberalism that is far too ready to countenance extremism in the service of liberal ideals where unpopular social and political movements are concerned. Mr. Schlesinger writes that ''the idea that the presence of a few Stalinists and fellow-travelers in the film industry was a grave threat to the republic rates high in the annals of Congressional asininity.'' One wonders, then, what clear and present dangers to the Republic could possibly have been averted by Mr. Kazan's collaboration with the House Un-American Activities Committee and its reckless ruination of talented lives.
docs.abstract: Letter from David Levering Lewis replies to Arthur Schlesinger Jr's Feb 28 Op-Ed deploring hypocrisy of those who protest award of honorary Oscar to Elia Kazan, who he informed on others during McCarthy era; says distinguished historians such as Schlesinger persist in conviction that victimization in defense of liberty is virtue

docs.lead_paragraph: NEWS Profit With Honor Already the recipient of 13 Oscar nominations, ''Shakespeare in Love'' led with 15 nominations yesterday when contenders for the 51st British Academy of Film and Television Awards were announced in London. The nominations included those for best picture, best director for John Madden, best actor for Joseph Fiennes and best actress for Gwyneth Paltrow. The other competitors for the prize for best film are ''Elizabeth,'' ''Saving Private Ryan'' and ''The Truman Show.'' The awards will be announced on April 11.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Hollywood Hypocrisy'' (Op-Ed, Feb. 28): There is no doubt that American Communists were grossly misguided, but their influence on the ideology of the American film industry was virtually nil. Probably this is because the commercial market dictated the type of profitable films that Hollywood produced, and not some self-appointed fanatics of doctrinaire political rectitude.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Hollywood Hypocrisy'' (Op-Ed, Feb. 28): Elia Kazan already has two Oscars: ''Gentleman's Agreement'' (1947) and ''On the Waterfront'' (1954). Only a self-congratulatory organization like the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences would think that he needs another. If Mr. Kazan should be honored for anything, it should be for his work in the theater, which revealed a far greater range than his films.
docs.abstract: Letter from Bernard F Dick says Elia Kazan has already received Oscars for two of his movies; says if he should be honored for anything, it should be for his work in theater, which revealed far greater range than his films

docs.lead_paragraph: Badgley Mischka Fills a Void With all the sports-utility minimalism overrunning fashion now, it should come as no surprise that there is an unquenched thirst for dress-up daytime suits. Who, after all, is thinking of the ladies who lunch? The omission has pushed Badgley Mischka to add a daytime collection. ''A lot of sportswear designers didn't do a lot of suits this year,'' James Mischka said. ''Everything was softer and about putting different pieces together.''

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    I was happy to see Maureen Dowd's Feb. 24 column on the brewing protest about the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences' giving Elia Kazan a lifetime achievement award. She gets the issue exactly right: it's about betrayal ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I was happy to see Maureen Dowd's Feb. 24 column on the brewing protest about the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences' giving Elia Kazan a lifetime achievement award. She gets the issue exactly right: it's about betrayal and cowardice, not about politics. Many great artists have held political affiliations or obnoxious attitudes that others abhor; if we denied honors to any artist who was also, say, misogynistic, racist, fascist or anti-Semitic, the pool would be severely depleted.

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Regarding Maureen Dowd's Feb. 24 column on the planned protests over the belated award given by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to the director Elia Kazan, unless Mr. Kazan apologies and recants, two questions occ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Regarding Maureen Dowd's Feb. 24 column on the planned protests over the belated award given by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to the director Elia Kazan, unless Mr. Kazan apologies and recants, two questions occur: If apologies are in order, shouldn't there be apologies from people who remained in the service of a dictator and mass murderer long after it was known that he was both? And would the arts community be so disturbed by Mr. Kazan's naming of names if the people whom Mr. Kazan identified were not Communists but unreconstructed Nazis? GEORGE MCKENNA New York, Feb. 24, 1999
